CHARLES GASCOYNE . I am potman to Mrs. Fear. I received a shilling from Connell for some beer—I told him it was bad—he said he took it from his master, and asked me to give it him back, which I did, and he put it into his pocket—I then asked my mistress if she had taken a bad shilling—I went to the till, took the shilling out, and said to Harrington, "You have given the lady a bad shilling"—he said he had not—I said he had, and he said, "I will give you good money for it"—he pulled out a sixpence, and then another sixpence—I gave the shilling I took out of the till, to the officer, and the officer was in the act of putting his hand into Connell's pocket, and Connell pulled out the shilling him
self which he had tendered to me.
Connell. Q. Did anybody drink in company with us? A. Not that I saw—I did not see any woman there—I had never seen you with Harrington before, to my knowledge.
Harrington. Q. What time did I come into your house? A. A little before dusk—it was half an hour or three-quarters after my mistress had the shilling that I had the other.
MICHAEL TROY (policeman, H 482). I was called and took the prisoners—I received one shilling from Gascoyne and another from Connell.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These shillings are both bad.
Connell's Defence. I was at work till half-past three o'clock, and I went for a pint of porter; if I had known the shilling was bad I had plenty of opportunity of making away with it.
Harrington's Defence. We left work, and there was singing in this house; we went and called for a pint of beer and paid for it.

CONNELL—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

HARRINGTON—
GUILTY . Aged 32.

166.
MARY JOHNSON was indicted
for a like offence.

ROBERT EDWARD SWYER . I am a surgeon, and live in Kennington-lane. On 25th Oct. the prisoner came for a pennyworth of antibilious pills—she gave me a sixpence—I put it at the back of my till, because I

thought her appearance suspicious—I tried the sixpence, and saw it was bad, and asked her how she dared to bring bad money, knowing it was bad—she said she brought it from her master, Mr. Johnson—I asked where she lived—she said two turnings up; she did not know the name of the street, nor the number—she wanted my boy to go—I said the officer should go.

WILLIAM BUDD (police-sergeant, L 49). I took the prisoner, and received this sixpence from Mr. Swyer—I asked the prisoner where she lived—she said two turnings from there—I knew there was but one turning, and I took her to the station—the searcher gave me this sixpence.

MARY SHERIDAN . As I was searching the prisoner at the Lambeth station I heard something fall from her dress—I saw a sixpence on the floor—I said, "You have dropped this sixpence from your hand"—she said, "I did not drop it from my hand; do not let them see it, I will be good to you when I go out; they do not know that I had it; they asked me whether I had any more, and it will be all the worse for me having that"—I gave the sixpence to the Inspector—he marked it in my presence, and gave it to the officer.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are both counterfeit, and from the same mould.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

167.
ROBERT GISSING
, unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his possession.

WILLIAM HANCKE . I live in Victoria-place, Clapham-road. On 15th Oct. I saw the prisoner and another lad at the bottom of the Lansdowne-road; they appeared in conversation—I saw the other boy in about five minutes come to the Landsdowne Arms for a quartern of gin—he tendered what appeared to be a shilling—the landlady refused it, and said it was bad—she took it in her hand and put it in the detector—the boy said he took it of a woman at the corner, with a black bonnet and a blue shawl—the potman and the boy went out to look for that woman, and I went with them—I saw the prisoner on the opposite side—I followed him till I lost sight of him at some new buildings—I turned up Larkhall-lane and over-took him—he came out from some building—I went and told him he must come with me to the Lansdowne Arms; he wanted to know what for—I told him I would tell him when I got him there—this was about twenty minutes before three o'clock—I do not know what became of the other boy—I believe the potman brought him back with the policeman.

Prisoner. Q. How long was I standing with the lad? A. You were standing talking with him on the right-hand side—the man who sweeps the crossing was there; I did not notice anybody else there—when you went alone you were trying to conceal yourself.

SAMUEL SIMPSON . On the afternoon of 15th Oct. I was in Sussex-place, Larkhall-lane, where there are some new buildings—I saw the pri
soner there—he first tried to make a hole with his heel by the side of a well—after he had done that, I saw him throw something white into the well—I went to the well and got on a board—I saw the last witness catch the prisoner—I emptied the water out of the well and found seven bad shillings—they were not wrapped up, but were on the top of one another—I took them to the station—I afterwards found one shilling in the well—I marked that as I had done the others, and gave it to the officer
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear that I chucked them in? A. I can swear that you threw something white in, and went away—I did not put them down myself.
WILLIAM ANGOVE (policeman, V 124). I went with the potman to the Lansdowne Arms, and took one lad; the landlord refused to prosecute him, and he was let go—I received this shilling from the potman.
ANN MOUSLEY . The shilling that was given to this officer, was the one that I received from the boy.
JOHN MARSHALL (police-sergeant, V 12). I produce seven bad shillings, which I received from Simpson.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This shilling that was uttered, and the seven found in the well, are all bad, and from the same mould.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

168.
THOMAS RODLEY
, stealing 1 skittle-ball, value 5s., the goods of
James Loughton; having been before convicted.

JAMES LOUGHTON . I am landlord of the Rose, in Tower-street, Waterloo-road, Lambeth. On 7th Nov. I met the prisoner going out at my back-door as I was coming in—I said there was no one there—he said he wanted to go backwards, and I suffered him to go—I had observed that my skittle-ball was safe when I came out of the yard—I had laid it down myself, and about eleven that night I missed it—I went after the prisoner and found him next door to a coffee-shop in the Waterloo-road—he said he knew nothing about it—I gave him in charge, and from some informa
tion I went the next day, between one and two, to Mr. Butcher's, at the Great Britain—I went into his skittle-ground and saw two skittle-balls—one of them I was confident was mine—this is it(produced)—here is a mark on one side and one on the other—I told Mr. Butcher it was mine, and he told me where he bought it—I went to Mr. Lockett's, at the Crown and Anchor, and asked him how he became possessed of it, and he told me.

Prisoner. Q. When I asked to go backwards did I not go? A. I do not know—I did not see you come out of the house—I was away on my business—I am sure no one went into my yard besides you—there are plenty of ways to go into my yard.

CHARLES LOCKETT . I was waiter at the Crown and Anchor in the Waterloo-road. On 7th Nov. I saw the prisoner there—I said I had been trying to sell a skittle-ball to Mr. Butcher, but it was not large enough—the prisoner said he had a ball about the size that Mr. Butcher wanted—he went and fetched it—I believe this is it—I asked him what he wanted for it—he said two shillings, and all I could get over that I might keep myself—I took it to Mr. Butcher's—he gave me 2s. 3d. and a pint of ale for it—I gave the prisoner 2s. and kept the 3d.
JONATHAN LARTER (policeman, L 106). I went to a coffee-shop on 8th Nov. and took the prisoner—he said he knew nothing about the ball.

Prisoner. I was taken once, and had three months, since then I have got my living honestly, as the officer knows. Witness. I have seen him in the neighbourhood of the New-cut—I do not know how he has got his living.

JESSE RUTLAND (police-sergeant, L 28). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read-
Thomas Owen, Convicted July, 1850; Confined three months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

169.
GEORGE FIELD
, stealing 16 1/4 lbs. weight of white lead, value 1s. 9d.; the goods of
James Bass, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Four Months.

170.
JOHN WEBB,
JOHN WELLS , and
HENRY WINKLETOP
, feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Wingate, and stealing 1 writing-desk, and other articles, value 4l. 2s., his property.

(Winkletop was also charged with
receiving,
and with harbouring Webb and Wells.)

GEORGE WINGATE . I reside in Spring-place, Wandsworth-road, Lam
beth. On 2nd Nov., I went to bed at a few minutes past eleven o'clock; I had fastened my doors and windows—I am satisfied every thing was perfectly fast—the next morning I came down at seven—I saw a light in the back-parlour, and found the window-shutters had been forced open, and the window was open—I missed sheets, counterpanes, and other things, which had been in the front-room, and which were brought into the back-parlour—I went to the station and came back—I then missed a writing-desk, which had been standing on a dining-table in the back-parlour—I had seen it safe the night before; and the counterpane, sheets, towels, an apron, and a watch—the watch was in my writing-desk, the other things were in the boxes which were under the the counter in the shop—they had been brought into the back-room, I had seen them safe the night before—any person could get from the back-parlour to the shop, without breaking any locks.

WILLIAM GIBBS , (policeman, V 77). From information I received I went to the prosecutor's house on the 3rd Nov., about half-past eight o'clock in the morning—I found some thieves had got over a fence five feet high, and then in at the back-window, by forcing the bolt and shutters, and forcing up the the window—that fence divides the premises of the prosecutor from a public thoroughfare—Spice was with me—I left the premises, and in a waste piece of ground I saw Webb walking to and fro, with a bag in his hand, and there was a load of gravel or sand—the fence divides the premises from the high-road which runs at the back of the premises; and the sand-heap was in an open piece of ground in front of the house—there is a road between the house and the waste ground—I was in plain clothes—I saw Webb go and sit down on the heap of sand, and he had a bag, as it appeared to be, under his arm—I went into the Wands-worth-road, and there I saw Wells—he went and joined Webb——they remained a few minutes, and then went away together, followed by Spice—I then went to the sand-heap, and examined it, and found the property which I now produce, tied up in two large bundles, covered over with the sand—I let it remain there for a few minutes, but some children being in the neighbourhood, began to run over the sand, and to remove one bundle—I then took the two bundles away and put them in the toll-house—at half-past five in the evening, just at dusk, I went with Spice, and took the same property back to where I found it, and covered it over with sand—we then went and watched for a few minutes, standing under a large wall—we then saw the three prisoners go up to the heap—we were thirty or forty yards from them; it was dark—I could see them by the gas light

—they were all at the sand, in a stooping position over the heap, at the spot where I had put the goods, which I had placed in the same part they had been in before—I then saw them all come away together, and Webb was carrying the property which was then all in one bundle in a sack—I could not see who put it in the sack, as they all stood round—when they came down to where I was standing, I caught hold of Webb, and said, "What have you got here?"—he said nothing, but dropped the sack—I took him and the sack to the station, with the assistance of another officer, and Spice took the other two prisoners—I examined the bundle, and found this desk, this watch, and all the property named—it was what I had discovered in the morning, and concealed.

COURT. Q. What were they wrapped up, in in the morning? A. The desk and the cloak were wrapped in a red handkerchief, which does not belong to the prosecutor; and the other things were wrapped in one of the towels.

Wells. At half-past eight o'clock that morning, I was far away from that place. Witness. I am sure I saw you there about half-past eight—I am certain of the exact time—it was about eight when I received infor
mation, and then I went and got nay things on, and went to the prosecutor's house.

Winkletop. Q. Could I not be passing that way without being in their company? A. You were in their company—you went up the gravel with them—I am certain there was nothing put with these things after I left them—what I put back, were the same, and no more, that I had left at the toll-house.

ALFRED SPICE (policeman, V 47). I went with Gibbs to the premises—I have heard what he has stated, which I confirm—I followed Webb and Wells in company—they were joined by two more men, near Old Vauxhall-gate—Winkletop was not one of the men—they all four walked some distance, and then Webb took one of the strange men in company, and walked on, and Wells took the other—I followed Webb, as he had the bag under his arm, over Westminster-bridge to Charing-cross, and to the Seven-dials, where the man who was with Webb, went into a lodging-house, and Webb turned down Church-lane, and I lost sight of him about eight or ten doors down—in the evening I assisted Gibbs in carrying back the property and burying it—I then watched and saw the three prisoners come up the back of Bradley-terrace, and go to the heap—they were all in a stooping position together—it was just under a lamp—they remained a short time, and then turned away, and I saw Webb was carrying this property on his shoulder—Gibbs took him, and I took the other two prisoners—they did not say anything—this is the property.
Wells. Q. Did you see me in the morning? A. Yes; about half-past eight o'clock, or it might be a little more—it was from half-past eight to nine o'clock.

GEORGE WINGATE
re-examined. This is all my property, I have no doubt, except the red handkerchief and the wrapper.
Webb's Defence. I had not been there on the Sunday morning; it was I that took the things from the heap; as for anything more I do not know; these two prisoners are innocent of that.
Wells's Defence. I was passing by on the Sunday evening; I saw the men stoop; I went to see what it was, and was taken.
Winkletop's Defence. I was standing at the corner of the street; I went to see what was the matter, and the officer said, "Take him too."

WILLIAM GIBBS
re-examined. When I saw Webb on the heap in the morning he did not disturb the sand at all—there were several persons passing—I should say I had not buried them in the evening above four or five minutes before the prisoners came.

WEBB—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

WELLS—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

WINKLETOP—
GUILTY of Receiving.
Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

171.
ANN WELLS
, stealing 1 purse, value 1s.; and 16 half-crowns, the property of
James Holland; from his person: having been before convicted.

JAMES HOLLAND . I am a printer, of Angler's-terrace, Peckham. On Sunday morning, 10th Nov., between one and two o'clock, I was in the Kent-road, near the corner of Trafalgar-road—I had a purse in my right pocket with ten half-crowns in one end, and six in the other—I had some halfpence in my pocket distinct from the purse—I saw the prisoner loiter
ing about the corner—just as I was about to enter the road she came up and took hold of my right arm—my right hand was in my trowsers pocket, and my left hand holding an umbrella—she persisted in accompanying me—I was going homewards—I turned up the Trafalgar-road—she made some remarks which I can scarcely charge my memory with—after I had crossed the canal bridge she asked me for money—as far as the bridge there is a carriage road, some houses on the right hand, and a great many on the left, and lamps; after that, it is a bye-road, and a footpath, there are no houses for a considerable distance—I made no request to her whatever—I did not acquiesce in her company, on the contrary, I wished to get away from her—Iwarned her that I was going home—I asked her to leave me in the first instance—I warned her that I was getting nearer and nearer home—I am a married man, and I thought it would be discreditable to be with her—she said she would not leave me without I gave her some money—that was a considerable distance after I had passed the bridge—I gave her some halfpence, all I had in my pocket, except what was in the purse—I thought it was only halfpence, but on making a calculation I found I had 11d.—I gave her a sixpence amongst the halfpence—at the moment I gave them to her, a policeman showed his light across the field—I said to her, "There is a policeman, now you had better go"—she did not go immediately, she continued where she was—I stood just for one minute, pointing to the policeman—she left me a minute afterwards, and within two minutes after, I discovered the loss of my money—I recollect having seen it about an hour before, and I had felt it not two minutes before—on finding that my money was gone I turned round immediately to the prisoner, and said, "You have taken my purse"—she had got but very few yards from me—she said, "I hope God may strike me blind and dead, if I have"—I told her she must give me my purse, it contained my children's victuals—I begged her to give it me—she seemed to pay no attention to anything I said, except repeating that she had not got it—I persisted that she had, for I knew a very short time before, it was safe in my pocket—at length when the policeman was approaching, she thrust the purse into my right hand—I immediately perceived that the money had

been taken from one end of it, but was left in the other—I found the six half-crowns had been taken from one end, the ten were left in the other— I found a hole about the centre of the purse, where there had been a slight hole previously, but it was increased—the ring had passed beyond the hole, so that there would be no rent where the money was—I said to her, "You have not given me all the money"—I told her she had got 15s. of my money, that I had had 2l., and now I had only got 25s.—I said, "Give it me"—she persisted that she had not got it—the policeman came up, and I gave her in charge—I had not had any service whatever from her from which she might have supposed she was entitled to any money.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where had you come from last before you saw her? A. From Trinity-street—I had been there to see if I could get some poultry—I had some friends coming to dinner the next day—there is a poulterer's shop there, on the right hand side going from the Borough—I had previously been to Partridge's, my grocer's, to boy my grocery—I did not leave my office in Stamford-street till nine o'clock—I am reader to a printer—I then went to Oakley-street for an umbrella, it was not done; I had to wait for it till ten—I then went to Shep
herd's, opposite Newington Church, where I had two glasses of ale and a biscuit for my supper—I staid there till a little after eleven—I then went to Mr. Partridge's, a grocer's—I got thereabout a quarter before twelve—I did not meet any one on my way—I staid there till a little after twelve, till I got my grocery—I then went back to Trinity-street, to buy some poultry—I did not get any—the shop was shut up—I then returned on my way home—when I got to the end of the road, I saw the prisoner loitering about—she walked a quarter of a mile with me, against my will—I saw no policeman—she had hard hold of my arm—if I had used force, I might have got rid of her—she was talking a parcel of rubbish, and about the Lord Mayor's show; there was nothing of an amatory nature—when I got to the end of the quarter of a mile, I stopped to get rid of her—I said I would not go any further—I then gave her some halfpence—I had my umbrella in my hand, and my grocery in a parcel—I did not put it out of my hand till I got to the station—I know there were several gates, I did not want her to go in at any of them—I found afterwards that I had given her 11d.—I gave her that to get rid of her—she did not go immediately—I was pointing to the policeman's light, and I said, "There is a policeman, you had better go"—she did not go for about a minute—I had these trowsers on which I have now, they have no button on this right-hand pocket, and the pocket is very shallow—I had a paletot on—she had gone three or four yards from me when I missed my purse—she did not run, she walked—I turned back, and came to her; I did not run—she was very unwilling to go till she had robbed me—I had received these half-crowns from Mr. Partridge, the grocer—his shopman is in the habit of changing my gold for silver every Saturday-night—there was not a wicket-gate that I wanted the prisoner to go in at, after I gave her the 11d., I felt too keen a sense of my moral situation as a married man.
MR. BRIARLY. Q. Do you persist now that you had received no service of any kind from her? A. Not any—I had not taken the slightest liberty with her.
GEORGJS WELLS (policeman, P 271). On Sunday morning, 10th Nov.,

between one and two o'clock, I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor in the Peckliam footpath—the prosecutor said, "You have robbed me"—the prisoner said she had not robbed him—I asked him; he said she had—I asked her, and she said she had not—he gave her in charge—she said she was innocent, and he ought to be ashamed to lock her up—he told me she took a purse, containing sixteen half-crowns, from him, and she gave him back the purse, containing ten half-crowns, and six were missing—she was searched by a female, and 1s. 6d. in silver was found on her, and 7 1/2 d. in copper—I searched the spot where the money was lost; I found nothing—there is water there—I said to the prisoner, "Has there been any connexion taking place between you and the gentleman?"—she said, "None whatever."

Cross-examined. Q. What was the first thing you heard; was not this woman crying? A. She was crying as I came up the street, but she had left off crying when I got to them—she said, "Don't lock me up, Sir, I am an innocent creature"—when I got up, he said she had taken 15s. from him—I received this money from the female searcher; I then went back to where they had been, and could not find the half-crowns.

Court. Q. Do you know that neighbourhood well? A. Yes; I know Angler's-place, Peckham—I know Trinity-street—the place where I saw the prosecutor, was directly in the way from Trinity-street to Angler's-place.
GUILTY . Aged 26.

JOHN MENHENNICK (police-sergeant, M 20). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction at this Court, by the name of
Ann Wales—(read—Convicted Sept., 1846, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the person—I was present.
Prisoner. I was never tried before.

MR. PAYNE. Q. How long did you have her? A. She was taken, I think, on 24th Aug., and tried on 21st Sept.—I took her about mid
night, and she was taken before the Magistrate the next morning—I did not take her to prison—I saw her tried, and I have seen her within the last twelve months—I have no doubt whatever she is the woman.

(THOMAS WEBB policeman, M 176, who was also present at the former trial, deposed to the prisoner's identity; and THOMAS MELVILLE, policeman, to her apprehension. The COURT, without taking a verdict, directed inquiry to be made: and on the following morning JOHN ALLEN, a turnkey, and a female turnkey from Brixton, stated that the prisoner had been confined there three months in 1846 MARY MORKIS, a turnkey at Horsemonger-lane, also remembered the pri
soner being there.)

172.
MICHAEL MILLER and
JOHN DUNNING
, stealing 50 prints for books, and 50 pieces of paper, value 4s.;
also, 6 printed books, 5s.;
also, 10 printed books, 2l.; the goods of
Thomas Edward Slate, their master: to all of which

MILLER pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 17.—He received a good character, and was recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
Confined Three Months,

DUNNING pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

173.
JOHN WILLIAMS and
JOHN COLLINS
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 8s.; the goods of
William Amos Marriage.—2nd COURT, for receiving: Williams having been before convicted: to which

WILLIAMS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Twelve Months.

COLLINS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

174.
JOHN COURTENAY
, feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Edward Jones, and stealing 144 metal taps, value 5l.; the goods of
John Doulton and another.

EDWARD JONES . I live at 29, High-street, Lambeth, and am in the service of Mr. John Doulton, and his partner, Mr. Watts—they an potters—I sleep in that house five nights in a week, and the other two I go into the country—besides the room I occupy, there are rooms used as store-rooms. On Saturday, 2nd Nov., I was at the premises till six o'clock in the evening—I was the last in the house—I locked it up, and took the keys with me—I had locked the outer and inner doors, and had the keys with me—the inner door leads from the front-room into the back-room—the front-room down-stairs and the back-room up-stairs are what I occupy—in the back-room down-stairs, were these taps, some sponge, and other valuable things—there is no way to the back-room but through the front-room—when I returned on the Monday morning, I found the outer door still fast—I unlocked it, and went in—the lower front-room has a window, which was open—it was shut when I left on Saturday—I saw a parcel of chips lying under the inner door—it had been cut, both on the door-post and opposite the lock, to facilitate the admission of an iron bar—the door was open, and the fastening was lying by it—I found an iron bar lying in the passage—I compared it with the indents—they cor
responded I missed from the back-room twelve dozen taps, which I had received from Mr. Hickman—I saw them on the Saturday, about six o'clock—it is my opinion that these (produced) are the same taps, with the name filed out—there are marks of a file—those taps I left, had the name of "Doulton and Watts" on them.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Is this house yours? A. It belongs to Messrs. Doulton and Watts, and there are seventy or eighty persons employed on the premises.

COURT. Q. Who enters that house? A. No one but myself; the work
men do not come in there—there are workshops besides that dwelling-house—the prisoner was never employed there—I do not know him.

JOHN HICKMAN . I live at Birmingham, and am a brass-cock founder. I was in the habit of supplying Mr. Doulton and his partner with brass taps—I sent them thirty dozen about a week or ten days before 2nd Nov.—hose produced by the officer are a portion of the stock I sent to Messrs. Doulton and Watts, to the best of my knowledge—they are our manufacture, and I have the punch that they are marked with—I supply no other house with the same sort of goods—here is the pattern they are cast from—they are all marked with the warehouse mark, a W.—these have not the marks on them, they have been filed off—the names are on the handles, and these handles are thinner and rougher than ours—we never turn out goods in this state.
Cross-examined. Q. You never made any of these taps for any other house? A. No, not of this sort—I have supplied other houses with other
descriptions of taps—I supply this house with this description by their order—these are made of yellow metal—I never supplied any other house with any of this metal.

THOMAS GARFORTH (policeman, L 151). From information on Friday, 8th Nov., I went to Mr. Simpson's shop in Lower-marsh, Lambeth—I found there three dozen of these brass taps—I afterwards went to the shop of Henry Fisk, a general outfitter for tobacconist's shops in the New-cut, where I found two dozen and eleven of these taps—I found one tap at the house of Mr. Bliss, a gas-fitter—on Saturday, 9th Nov., I saw the pri
soner go into a public-house in the New-cut—I went in after him, and said, "You must consider yourself in my custody for having had a quan
tity of brass taps in your possession"—he said, "I have been to Doulton and Watts this morning"—he did not say for what purpose—I had not mentioned the name of Doulton and Watts to him—I asked him how he came by them—he said he bought them at a sale in Leicester-square—I asked him if he knew the man he bought them of—he said he was a dark Jew-looking man, with a thin nose—I asked him if he had a catalogue of the sale—he said, "No," the sale had commenced about an hour before he got there—he afterwards said he bought them at Jones's sale-room on Monday the 4th, in the evening—there is an auctioneer of that name—there are two auction-rooms, but Mr. Jones's is not in Leicester-Square, it is two doors down a passage—the prisoner described the place where he bought them—he said, "Jones's is at the further end of Leicester-square," which would be the further end from the police-court—I went to another auction-room, Mr. Thomas's—I got a catalogue from Mr. Thomas".

COURT. Q. There is another auction-room in Leicester-square? A. Yes, Mr. Thomas's, which is three doors from Green-street; that is in the square—I was informed by the foreman that the prisoner had been to Messrs. Doulton's.

HENRY ADAMS SIMPSON . I am a marine-store dealer, of the New
cut, Lambeth. On Monday, 4th Nov., I saw the prisoner in my house about twelve o'clock in the day—I have known him fifteen years, he attends sale-rooms—I never knew anything wrong of him—he buys lots, and sells them in the trade to ironmongers, marine-store dealers, and furni
ture dealers—he called on me that Monday about twelve o'clock, and said he was going to Jones's sale-room for twelve dozen of taps to be sold, what would I give him for them—I know Jones's sale-rooms; they are called in Leicester-square; they are within two doors of it—I do not know whether they have any window which looks into Leicester-square—I said I could not tell what to give for them unless I saw them—on the following Thurs
day he brought me a sample tap—I told him I would take three dozen at 7s. a dozen—he came back in about two hours, and said he had sold three dozen to Fisk, and six dozen to another place, and I should have the three dozen, and I had them—he came back about five o'clock, and brought the three dozen with him.

Cross-examined. Q. You have known him fifteen years? A. Yes, he has been dealing at my shop—I always thought him a respectable young man—it is a common thing for parties to buy things at sales, and sell them at a profit; that is the way he has got his living—he was well known in the trade—all the brokers in the Cut know him—I never bought taps of him before.

MR. HICKSON re-examined. Q. What is the price of these taps? A. Eight and sixpence a dozen, with two and a half per cent. off and carriage paid, which reduces them to about eight shillings and twopence a dozen,

WILLIAM FISK . I am foreman to my uncle, Henry Fisk, a shop-fixture dealer in the New-cut. On 6th November the prisoner came to our shop, between ten and twelve o'clock in the morning—he brought me one tap, and asked me whether the taps would suit my uncle—he said he had about three dozen—he came again about one o'clock and brought thirty-four more—he had left the sample one—he said he would call on Saturday, about two o'clock, to ascertain whether my uncle would have them—I said, "They will not suit the governor; they are not long enough"—he came on Saturday, and I told him they would not suit—the officer came to our shop on Friday evening—when the prisoner called on Saturday I told him to take them away.

COURT. Q. You say he came on Wednesday with a sample, and he came again later and brought thirty-four? A. Yes; I told him to leave them and come again on Saturday—he did not come to our place on the Satur
day—he was opposite, and I told the officer that was the man, and he went and took him.

Q. Then when was it you told him the taps would not suit? A. I think it was on the Thursday—he came again on the Thursday, the next day, and then he said, "I will call again on Saturday"—he asked me if he might leave them, as he was going on further—no time was fixed for his coming on Saturday—he said he would come about Saturday—he asked seven shillings and sixpence a dozen for them—he did not tell me where he got them—I did not ask him.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. The last six years—he has been in the habit of dealing at our house almost every day—he has sold us things—it is customary for persons in that way to buy things at auctions and pawnbrokers—I am sure he said he would call on Thursday, and he did call—I knew him to be a very good, fair-dealing man—I never knew anything against his character; if he got any profit he would be satisfied—I have been in the Cut seven years, in my uncle's service—he has been known at our house fifteen years—I do not know where he lives—when I saw him on the Saturday he was walking along on the other side of the way.

MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Are you in the habit of buying new articles from him? A. Sometimes—I never bought any taps of him—he was in the habit of selling cheap—the slightest profit would satisfy him—he would bring counting-house railings and other things.

GEORGE AARON . I am in the employ of Mr. Bliss, of 20, New-cut, Lambeth. On 6th Nov. I saw the prisoner at my master's shop with one of these taps as a sample for my employer to look at—I rather think he said how many he had got, but I do not remember—he said he had a quantity of taps for sale—I think he called several times during the day, to know whether Mr. Bliss approved of them—he called on Friday and saw Mr. Bliss, who said he would purchase them—I was present and advised Mr. Bliss to purchase them, as they would suit us—he agreed to purchase six dozen, at seven shillings and sixpence a dozen—two guineas were paid for them, which is a fair value—we could purchase the same articles new for a halfpenny more each—I do not know whether we have ever bought taps
like these—we have had new taps from Birmingham—I consider they might have been purchased at seven; shillings and sixpence, or eight shillings.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Some years—he has been in the habit of dealing at our house, buying and selling—I never heard anything wrong of him—he has been allowed to select goods in our shop—he has sold such goods as he might buy at sales.

MR. O'BRIEN. Q. What articles has he sold at your shop? A. Goods of various descriptions—we are gas-fitters—I rather think we have bought taps of him before, with other goods; not very recently—my master is in the miscellaneous way, he purchases other things—the prisoner lives some where close by us—he said he purchased these taps at a sale-room; I am not certain whether he said Jones's.

JOSEPH HONNOR . I am a porter in the employ of Mr. Jones, in Lei
cester-street, Leicester-square, an auctioneer—there is no other auctioner of that name in Leicester-square—I have been in his employ four years—I do not recollect seeing the prisoner there—the regular days for our sales are Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays—I cannot undertake to say the prisoner has not been there—I recollect Monday 4th Nov.—there was no sale there that evening nor on that day—there has been no taps like these sold at Mr. Jones's—there was no sale on Tuesday 5th Nov., nor any taps sold of this description—there was a sale on Wednesday 6th— —there were no taps of this description sold in that week, nor the week before—I was present at all the sales all the time—about twelve months ago we had an ironmonger's stock sold—we sold some taps, but not twelve dozen.

Cross-examined. Q. You cannot swear that taps might not have been sold without your knowledge? A. Not in the sale—they might have been sold in the sale-room, that is done at times—persons come to the sale with lots and sell them without their being in the catalogue—persons attending other sales knowing that dealers are in our room, come in the afternoon and sell them by private contract in the room—the sale-rooms are open other days for men to bring goods in—the articles are on view on Wednesday morning—the rooms are open on Monday and Tuesday for taking in articles—articles might not on these days be sold by private contract—we begin on Monday night to make the catalogue, and we allow no one to enter except to bring goods—as many as half-a-dozen persons might be there—I cannot undertake to say that goods might not be sold by private contract—brokers and persons of that sort meet at our doors and do business—Mr. Thomas's auction-rooms are in the square—their sales are on Mondays and Thursdays.

MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Were you at Mr. Jones's rooms on that Monday? A. Yes; I live there—I am always there—except on auction days no persons are allowed to come there to traffic—they are not allowed to be in the room to make a sale—if two dealers meet there to make a sale, they would be told to go down-stairs and settle it—I was there on the Tuesday—the sale commences on Wednesday at six o'clock in the evening.

EDWARD JONES
re-examined. I am the only person who occupies this house—I keep the key of the outer-door and of the room where the pro
secutor's goods are—I pay no rent nor taxes—I live on part of my master's premises—the family never sleep there—the prisoner did come to Doulton.
and Watts—I am not certain on what day—Mr. Doulton told him it was in the hands of the police.

COURT to GEORGE AARON. Q. On the Saturday on which the prisoner was apprehended, was he in your shop? A. Yes, in the morning—he came respecting the taps—I learned from him that he had seen Mr. Bliss—the officer had been to our house in the morning—the names of Doulton and Watts were mentioned, but Mr. Bliss had heard of this robbery before he went to look for the prisoner.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

175.
HENRY WRIGHT and
JOHN LEARY
, robbery on
Frederick Williams, and stealing 1 hat, value 2s.; and beating and striking him.

FREDERICK WILLIAMS . I live in Surrey-row, Blackfriars-road. On 5th Nov., I was going down Charlotte-street about half-past ten o'clock at night—I saw a mob of persons—as soon as they saw me coming, they opened, and as soon as I got in the centre of them, some one knocked my hat off—there were seven persons standing together—it was just at the entrance, going into Mr. Sherman's house—when Wright knocked me down on the pavement, the girls and boys held me down, and Wright turned my poc
kets inside out, and ill-used me while I was down—I had a penny-piece in my pocket, and some bits of paper—Wright gave me two black eyes, and struck me with his fist and the stump of his arm—Leary held me while I was down—when my hat was knocked off, one of the other boys ran away with it—while I was on the ground, the whole of them held me tight—there were two more boys about the size of the prisoners, and three young women—they held me so as to allow Wright to make his escape—Leary was one who held me—my penny was not stolen; it was in my trowsers-pocket—Wright turned out two of my pockets, but not the one where my penny was—the hoys and girls told Wright to get away while they held me—I was knocked down two or three times with great force—Wrightgot way, and I got from the others, and followed him up William-street to near Swan-court—when he got near Swan-court, he told the other two boys to seize me, and while they were in the act of seizing me, he ran down Swan-court—they did not seize me, but Wright got down Swan-court, and knowing them to be bad characters there, I did not go after him—I had seen him once before—I am positive the prisoners are the persons.

Cross-examined by MR. WOOLLETT. Q. You know this neighbour
hood well? A. Yes, I have lived there four years; this mob of boys and girls were not Guy Fawkes-ing—the street was clear then; it was half-past ten o'clock at night—I should not know the whole of the seven per
sons again, but I know these two particularly—the boys and girls were standing on the path till I got to the centre of them—I did not push them on one side—I was going home—I had been to the New-cut to a coffee-shop there—my work is at 30, Surrey-row—I am a master-hatter's son—my father carries on business there—I had been working in the day, and I went by myself in the evening to read the newspaper in the coffee-shop in the New-cut—I was knocked down two or three times—I cried out to the utmost of my power—I did not cry "Murder!" I cried "Police!"—they might have put me in fear of my life; they did not do it—I resisted, I had a right to do so—Wright gave me two black eyes—I did not give him one—I did my best—I do not say I did not hit him.

JOHN RICHARD GOLTON (policeman, M 62). I was on duty on the night of 5th Nov., near the Chapel in the Blackfriars-road—I saw Wright in company with two other boys, about a quarter-past ten o'clock—Leary was one of the boys.

WILLIAM BROAD (policeman, L 82). I apprehended Wright on 8th Nov.—I told him the charge was assaulting this man, and robbing him of his hat—the prosecutor had two black eyes on the night of 8th Nov. when he gave me information—I knew Wright by the description he gave, and I took him about a quarter of an hour afterwards.
AMBROSE FURMINGER (police-sergeant, L 42). I received information on 12th Nov., and took Leary.

FREDERICK WILLIAMS
re-examined. I gave information to the police the same night—I should say that the girls who were there, were about twenty years of age.

JOHN RICHARD GOLTON
re-examined. I received information from the prosecutor about half-past ten o'clock that night—he described Wright to me—I had seen him that night, but I did not know where to find him.

WRIGHT—
GUILTY .†* Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

LEARY—
GUILTY .†* Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

176.
ANN CHAPMAN
, stealing 13 half-shawls, Value 7s.; the goods of
Thomas Southon and another; having been before convicted.

GEORGE GERRY WILSON . I am a banker's clerk, and live at Peckham. On 21st Nov., about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was going along the Old Kent-road—I had not observed the prosecutor's shop before, but I did on that occasion—while I was passing I saw the prisoner standing looking in at the window, and as I passed she turned round to watch me—I walked on, and in a minute or a minute and a half, she ran past me, carrying something in her arms—I ran after her, and after running 200 or 300 yards I came up to her and laid hold of her arm—she immediately threw these shawls down—I told her she must come back to the shop from which she took these shawls—she said, "I did not take them; I picked them up"—I asked her if she picked them up why she ran away so fast—she said she never ran at all—she was running; I was quite out of breath when I came up to her—I took her back, and the prosecutor gave her into custody.

THOMAS SOUTHON . I am a linen-draper, carrying on business with my brother, in the Old Kent-road. On the evening of 21st Nov. the prisoner was brought to my shop, with these shawls, which had been hanging in the lobby—I had not sold any shawls of this description that day—my brother and two young men serve in my shop—I saw these shawls safe about two o'clock—neither of the persons in my shop sold so many shawls as these, if any were sold it would have been only one or two—they were tied in the lobby with a string.
JOHN VARNEY (policeman, P 333). I received the prisoner into custody—these are the shawls—she said she picked them up on the pavement.
Prisoner. As I was passing, I picked the parcel up; I ran across the road, but did not run away.
HENRY HILL (policeman, L 154). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted May, 1849; Confined three months)—she is the person.

GUILTY .*—
Confined Twelve Months.

177.
GEORGE INGRAM
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 5s.; the goods of
Erasmus Stevens, from his person; having been before convicted.

ERASMUS STEVENS . I live in Chapel-place, Brixton-road. On 6th Nov., about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, I was walking in the Kennington-road, and the prisoner and another boy came running round me two or three times—the third time, I felt something at my coat behind —the witness Craig, who was riding in a cart with my wife, called out to me, and I missed my handkerchief from my right-hand coat-pocket—I had had it in my hand not five minutes before, and had put it into that pocket—my coat-lap was torn or cut nearly through—I ran after the prisoner, and saw him in Frederick's-place, about ten yards from where I had seen him first—he had my handkerchief in his hand—I caught hold of him just as he was going into a house in Frederick's-place, and struck him on the side of the head, and he threw the handkerchief down at my feet, and ran into the house—I called, "Police!"—a policeman came directly, and after some time we got admission—I gave him into custody, with the handkerchief—we found him just inside the door, with another boy.

JAMES CASTLETON (policeman,). I was called by Mr. Stevens to the door of 9, Frederick's-place—the door was opened after I had knocked a great many times, and I found the prisoner and one or two of his brothers standing behind it—Stevens pointed out the prisoner—I told him what I took him for—he said he knew nothing of it, that there was another boy there besides him.

JOHN CRAIG . I was driving a cart on the evening of 6th Nov.—Stevens's wife was with me, and he was walking in the road—I saw two boys playing round him two or three times—I said, "Stevens, you are copped"—he said, "What do you mean?"—I said, "You are robbed"—I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief out of Stevens's pocket.

WILLIAM BROAD (policeman, L 82). I produce a certificate—(read—George Ingram, convicted here, Aug., 1850, of embezzlement, confined four
teen days, and once privately whipped)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person.
GUILTY .** Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.

178.
JOSEPH WHITE
, embezzling the sums of 1s. 6d. and 2s.: also,1l.; the moneys of
Steven Eastwood, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Four Months.

179.
GEORGE FAIRCLOTH
, embezzling the sums of 5s. 5 1/2 d., 4s. 1d., and 5s. 9d.; the moneys of
Andrew White, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Four Months.

180.
WILLIAM BRIFFITH
, stealing, in Middlesex, 27 balls of twine and 1 ball of cord, value 12s. 6d.; the goods of
William Austin;
also, stealing 66 balls of twine, 1 ball of box-cord, and 18 yards of whip-cord, value 17s. 9d.; the goods of
Henry Adolphus Fisher: to both which he pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy. — Confined

181.
JOHN BATES
, feloniously forging and uttering a receipt for 1l. 2s. 10d., with intent to defraud
James Abbot;
also, stealing 10 sove
reigns, and 20 half-sovereigns; the moneys of
James Abbott, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 41.—
Confined Fifteen Months.

182.
HENRY JOHNSON,
EDWARD COOPER,
WILLIAM HARRIS , and
WILLIAM HALL
, stealing 2 pewter-pots, value 3s.; the goods of
William Taylor: Johnson having been before convicted: to which

HARRIS—pleaded
GUILTY .** Aged 16.

HALL—pleaded
GUILTY .** Aged 17.

SAMUEL EASTMENT (policeman, T 7). On 5th Nov., a little before four o'clock in the morning, I was in the Clapham-road; the four prisoners and another, passed me—I followed them to Clapham-common—I heard a whistle from one of them, they then ran across from a public-house to the other side of the way, and then towards London—I saw a policeman on that side of the way—Hall ran away for a few yards—I seized him; he had this quart pot(produced) in his coat-pocket—he said, "I have got nothing"—Cooper threw a pot into a garden, the other policeman picked it up—it has on it, "William Taylor, Clapham"—Johnson said, "You have no business to take me; I am a respectable person; I should not have spoken to the others, if I had seen them in the street."
Johnson. I had only been in their company occasionally a few minutes. Witness. I had seen him with them for half-a-mile.

WILLIAM EMSLEY . I am superintendent of Shoreditch workhouse. I know the prisoners; Johnson, Cooper, and Harris, are brothers, their name is Rawlings; the other one is Joseph Boley—I have known them three years, and have had them in custody many times—they all came to the relieving-officer the night before this, and had half-a-quartern loaf each; they said they had got work to-morrow.
WILLIAM MEW . I am in Mr. Taylor's service. These pots are his—I missed them on 5th Nov.—I had cleaned them the day before.

Johnson's Defence. I was going to the races to get a job, and met these three; I had a handful of victuals; they asked me to give them some; I did so; the policeman looked to see what I had got and was satisfied; I could have gone away if I had been guilty.
Cooper's Defence. I was with the others, but turned back as my throat was sore and my shoes bad; the policeman came; the pot was found over the railings, and it was laid to me.

BENJAMIN EMSLEY
re-examined. I produce a certificate from this Court—( read—
Benjamin Rawlings, Convicted July, 1848, of robbery; Trans
ported for seven years)—Johnson is the person—I had him in custody—I have heard him say he got off transportation by gammoning the doctor.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

COOPER—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

183.
SARAH FREEMAN
, stealing 1 watch and guard, value 7l. 10s., the goods of
George Bullock Garland, her master, in his dwelling-house.

GEORGE BULLOCK GARLAND . I live in Brook-street, Lambeth. The prisoner was in my employ two months—on Saturday, 16th Nov., I missed the key of a cupboard, had it forced open, and missed my watch and guard, which I had put there on the Thursday—I went to the workshop where the prisoner was, told her I had lost them, and sent for Goff; he came, and asked her if she knew anything of my missing my watch—she said she had heard of it but she did not take it; she had never seen it—she afterwards said it was all false what she had said, she had taken the watch and given it to the young man she was keeping company with.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (policeman, L 8). I went to the house and asked the prisoner if she had seen the watch in the cupboard—she said she had not—I asked what time she left on the Friday evening—she said she left at five and returned at half-past—I asked where she had been—she said she had been home to tea, and her mother sent her to the doctor's as her sister was ill—I went to her mother's, found that was not correct, and then she said she had given the watch to her young man—I then went to 135, Broad wall, where Plumb resides—he was not at home—I afterwards saw him, and received this watch and chain from him—(produced).

THOMAS GARFORTH (policeman, L 151). I took the prisoner—as we went to the station she said, "When Mr. Garland went to the back par
lour for the lucifers, I saw a tall man there; he looked at me and gave me the watch, and said, 'I shall see you again outside;' I was not to say anything to anybody; I took the watch, and not seeing him again, I kept it and gave it to the young man; he asked me how I became possessed of and I told him I found it."

HENRY PLUMB . I am apprentice to Mr. Brown, a brass-founder; I live at 135, Broadwall; I am the prisoner's young man. On the Friday I saw the prisoner in Brook-street, and she gave me the watch—I asked her how she came by it; she said she found it in Kennington-lane, under a lamp-post, wrapped in a piece of paper—I showed it to my master the next day—I saw Goff the same day and gave it to him.

GEORGE BULLOCK GARLAND
re-examined. This is my watch, and what was in the cupboard.

184.
CHARLES PESCUD
, stealing 2 shillings, 2 sixpences, 2 pence, and 2 halfpence:
also 2 shillings, 2 sixpences, 2 pence, and 2 halfpence;
also 1 half-crown, 1 sixpence, and 3 pence; the moneys of
Charles Ellis, his master: to all of which he pleaded
GUILTY .

p.hi:
He received a good character.—
Confined Three Months

div1.p:
185.
TIMOTHY MAHONEY
, stealing 9 bagatelle balls, value 30s.; the goods of
Charles Walker: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

186.
HENRY CHALK
, unlawfully breaking and entering the dwell
ing-house of
Rosanna Duke, with intent to steal.

ROSANNA DUKE . I am a widow, and live at 20, Tennison-street, York-road, in the parish of St. Mary, Lambeth. On Saturday night, 2nd Nov., I fastened my door at half-past nine o'clock—I sleep on the ground-Boor front—on Sunday morning, about half-past six, I heard some one come on the step of my door—a short time afterwards, I heard some one scrape their shoes, and put a key into the door, and not knowing the door was unbolted I felt no concern—I called my servant, heard another attempt, and heard the latch open, and a person walk in, and go up the hall towards the staircase—I went towards the stairs, and saw the shadow of some one about a yard and a half from the front parlour door—I called my servant again, very loudly, and the party turned round and went out, slamming the door—I cannot say who it was—I was agitated—there was no one but my servant and me in the house—the prisoner was afterwards brought back by a policeman—he is not a lodger of mine—I gave him into custody.

ELLEN HARRIGAN . I am Mrs. Duke's servant, On the night of 2nd Nov. I came in with some beer, and fastened the door on the latch, but did not bolt it—in the morning I saw the policeman bring the prisoner to the house.

WILLIAM WESTON (policeman, L 65). I know the prisoner—I have seen him several times—on this Sunday morning I saw him start from home, in White-horse-street, New-cut, and followed him and another party to Stamford-street, Blackfriars-road—I saw him go to the door of No. 27 or 28 there, and fumble at the key-hole, and try to open it—he did not open it, and walked away, looking at all the doors till he got into Tennison-street, where I saw him go to Mrs. Duke's door, No. 20—he scraped his feet, stood for a minute or two at the door, while some parties were coming by, and after they had passed he opened the door, apparently with a key, and walked in—I ran down Sutton-street, and when I came back he had run out, and run to Commercial-road—he returned to the house again, but did not go in—he went up to the door, apparently to try it again, and then ran away again down the Belvidere-road, where I took him, and took him back to the house—Mrs. Duke sent her servant to the station-house with us, where I searched him, and found two keys on him, one of whichopens Mrs. Duke's door—I was forty yards from the house when I saw him go in, and I ran round Sutton-street, to get as near as I could without passing the door, as I was afraid it might be open—I left some one watching.

GUILTY .*Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 16TH, 1850.
